title: Richard Skinner and Jen Dalton Draft Kings lineups Week 6
text:
Richard Skinner and Jen Dalton Draft Kings lineups Week 6 
Updated: Fri, Oct 16 2015, 01:22 PM 
CINCINNATI (Richard Skinner) -- Local12 reporter Jen Dalton and I are playing fantasy football this season at DraftKings.com and a little further below are the lineups we selected for the Millionaire Maker contest for games that will be played on Sunday and Monday. 
Draft Kings offers one week contests that don't lock participants into season-long teams and the contest in which we are participating doesn't include the Thursday night game, which will be the case almost every week this season. 
Our lineups will be on Local12.com each Friday and you can see us explain our picks each Saturday night on Bengals Nation, which starts at 11:35 p.m. on Local12. 
Here are our lineups and my explanation below (you can see Jen's reasoning and more of mine on Bengals Nation) in addition to a rating system for Bengals players' fantasy value this week (note: you can't see lineups on our mobile app, so go to desktop to view): 
RICHARD SKINNER 

WHY I MADE MY SELECTIONS 
The Skinny: Keep in mind when picking lineups each week that there is a salary cap, and Dalton provides great value right now. He torched one of the best secondaries in the NFL last Sunday and no reason he shouldn't put up good numbers against a suspect Buffalo secondary - especially at the safety positions - and the Bengals could have a tough time running the ball, too. 
Lacy isn't off to a great fantasy start (51.4 yards per game and only one touchdown), but he's facing a Chargers defense that is allowing 132.4 yards per game rushing, which ranks 29th in the NFL. Murray got off to a horrible start, too, but he had 27 touches for 120 yards and a touchdown last week and that seems more in line what he can do each week. 
Edelman is a stat monster, averaging 8.5 catches for 99.8 yards per game and with three touchdown receptions in four games. Marshall has been consistently very good, too, averaging 7.5 receptions for 100.0 yards per game and with three touchdowns in four games as well. I went for some value with both Boldin and Brown. Boldin is facing a Baltimore pass defense that ranks 25th in the NFL, while Brown is averaging almost five receptions for 60 yards and is facing a pass defense ranked 20th. 
With Buffalo's problems at safety I am hoping Eifert can have as big a game as he had in week one in Oakland and last week against Seattle. 
The Vikings have a solid defense and are facing a Kansas City Chiefs offense that is now without Jamaal Charles and can't protect quarterback Alex Smith. 
BENGALS FANTASY VALUE 
Each week I rate the Bengals fantasy players value on the following system: touchdown means must play; field goal means it's a good play; first down means play only if you have to play him; punt means don't play at all: 
Touchdown (must play): WR A.J. Green (he is a must-play virtually every week); QB Andy Dalton (he's off to a great start, is averaging 303 yards and two touchdown passes per game and facing a defense that's tough to run against and average at best against the pass); TE Tyler Eifert (he is arguably a top five fantasy tight end). 
Field Goal (good play): Defense/Special Teams (Bengals defense allowed significant yards the last three games, but is sacking QB, likely facing erratic E.J. Manuel and it feels like Adam Jones is about to bust a punt return for a TD). 
First Down (play only if you have to play him): RB Jeremy Hill (had three touchdowns against Kansas City and is top candidate around the goal line, but having a hard time getting untracked); RB Giovani Bernard (has been outstanding in his role the first five games, and is averaging 94 yards per game from scrimmage, but has just one TD); K Mike Nugent (he's coming off being named AFC Special Teams Player of the Week and is a candidate to be a solid producer each week because of the Bengals offense, although weather is a concern); WR Marvin Jones (bounced back from disappointing game against Kansas City to have five catches for 61 yards and last time he faced a Rex Ryan coached team he had four touchdown catches); WR Mohamed Sanu (had nine catches for 153 yards last two games after only five catches for 77 yards in first three games). 
Punt (don't play at all): Anyone else. 
Follow us on Twitter @Local12 and LIKE us on Facebook for updates! 
To get "The Skinny" on local sports be sure to follow Local12 Digital Sports Columnist/Editor Richard Skinner on Twitter @Local12Skinny and LIKE him on Facebook for updates or email him raskinner@sbgtv.com. Related Stories
